data.title: [PHP] Code coloration for multiline queries
data.body:
Hi, 
When try to make a multiline database query, the syntax colouration is bad...

``` php
            $newUser = $db->prepare("INSERT INTO users".
                "(id, realname, pseudo, email, pwd, isfirstvisit)".
                "VALUES (:id,:realname,:pseudo,:email,:pwd,1)");

```

(just like markdown :) )

data.title: Hotkey collide with 'ś' letter on polish keyboard
data.body:
In Polish language exists letter 'ś', written by pressing rightAlt+s. In atom this combination brings up the 'Spec suite' window. 
Worth noticing is fact, that in settings shortcut responsible for this is **ctrl**-alt-s, yet rightAlt+s alone brings up the window too.
I tried adding 

```
'body':
  'ralt-s': ''
  'ctrl-alt-s' : ''
```

to the keymap, but it didn't fix my problem.

Expected change: 
- chaning default shortcut to a non-colliding one 
  or
- making only ctrl-alt-s as hotkey and not rightAlt-s,

data.title: Shadow DOM prevents styles.less from customizing syntax elements?
data.body:
If I'm understanding the blog article and corresponding documentation correctly, UI theme stylesheets are loaded (for lack of better terms) in the "workspace" context and Syntax theme stylesheets are loaded in the "editor" context. And they are prevented from conflicting with each other. It appears from my experimentation that the `styles.less` is loaded in the workspace context and that it cannot modify syntax styles anymore (with the Shadow DOM enabled). (See the Repro Steps section for an example.)

Should we have two user stylesheets now? Perhaps `ui-styles.less` and `syntax-styles.less`?

**cc** @nathansobo 
## Repro Steps
1. Launch Atom
2. Open the Settings View (<kbd>Cmd+,</kbd> on OS X)
3. Ensure "Use Shadow DOM" is _not_ checked
4. Ensure that the "Atom Light" syntax theme is selected
5. Open `styles.less`
6. Add the following content:
   
   ``` LESS
   // Test
   
   .editor, :host {
       .comment {
           font-style: normal;
       }
   }
   ```
7. Verify that the "Test" comment is _not_ italicized
8. Open the Settings View
9. Check "Use Shadow DOM"
10. Close and restart Atom

**Expected:** "Test" comment should not be italicized
**Actual:** "Test" comment is italicized
## Versions
- **Atom:**       0.154.0-de36ceb
- **Atom-Shell:** 0.19.4
- **OS:**         Mac OS X 10.10.1
- **Misc**
  - apm  0.111.1
  - npm  1.4.4
  - node 0.10.33
  - python 2.7.6
  - git 1.9.3

---

<small>This report was created in and posted from the Atom editor using the package `bug-report` v0.5.3.</small>

data.title: Atom just crashes when opening large files
data.body: Before, Atom used to just be super slow when working with large files, but it seems to have regressed to the point where Atom just doesn't respond and needs to be force closed.

data.title: Roadmap
data.body: It would be nice to have a couple milestones regarding alphas/betas/rc's up to 1.0.0 so that people no more of what is really going on.

data.title: Hack Invalid File Type
data.body:
[Hack](https://github.com/facebook/hhvm) is the next generation of PHP by Facebook. It uses .hh as it's extension, but Atom detects it as a C++ file, which means the syntax highlighting is not appropriate.

So .hh extension should be associated with PHP or Hack in the Next Release. and until then, how can I force PHP as the filetype to all of my .hh files? At the moment Atom only allows me to temporarily change it by Clicking C++ on the footer and Selecting PHP from the list.

data.title: Add atom.services API
data.body: This depends on the [`service-hub`](https://github.com/atom/service-hub) library, but I wanted to make the documentation Atom-specific in the project so I'm defining a trivial subclass in core. It's kinda weird, but gets the job done. Open to suggestions as to other approaches. Check out the [documentation](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/ns-add-services-api/src/service-hub.coffee) at the top of the `ServiceHub` class on this branch for more details about the design.

data.title: Interacton of marker overlays
data.body:
Marker overlays are a great new addition to atom.  I have a few cases I would like to see handled in the future. 
- when I have multiple overlays on screen, some options for how you would like the overlays to interact
  - attempted to layout such that they don't overlay each other
  - when they are attached to the same marker attempt to dock overlays together such that they appear in concert
- when a cursor or other editor driven marker would be obscured by an overlay we could push it in a different direction.
- when a mouse intersects an overlay it would be nice to have some standard interaction options.  
  -  hide on mouse intersects
  -  fade out on mouse intersects,  ideally this level would allow you to place a cursor behind it and highlight text ranges.
  -  fully interactable with mouse
- in order to better prioritize multiple overlays for positioning and or removal there should probably be a priority setting
  - low: used for informational overlays that can be obscured or removed by higher priority items
  - medium: used for errors and warning overlays that should be prioritized over other informational overlays
  - high: used for interactive popups that can have mouse, and keyboard interactions associated with them, these are positioned very aggressively removing any informational popups if they don't fit in.

Ideally we would have some patterns to follow regarding how to create overlays.
